intro: ^Some bubble tea places go all out. Cheese, burnt cheese, fresh taro, purple rice, rice and yoghurt.
^You know how people read tea leaves? It's called "tasseography", I found out. It's really big with mums on Pinterest now.
^So, I read an article in Harper's. I thought I might be able to do the same.
^They tend to look down on us. But I'd argue it's an art in itself.
^We're at the brink of a new age. A new period in human occupation, where everyone's troubles and anxieties can just bubble away.

c-1: ^ Um, just let me check real quick...

g-1: ^Customer: "Almond will do. Whatever. A 'Wasting My Youth Away Going to Art Gallery Openings Every Weekend' Peach and Taro Golden Rain Tea, please? Normal size. Cold, with less sugar, a bit of ice."

choose_sugar: ^I got pretty good at knowing how people wanted it.

c-1: ^ I'm guessing you want it less sweet.
c-3: ^ You look like you'd want more sugar. Am I right?

choose_ice: ^How much ice they wanted. You could see it in their eyes, most of the time.
small_talk: ^I don't even know if the tea was any good. Sometimes they just tipped it out into the gutter and handed the cup back over for a reading.

c-1: ^. We have our regulars. Surprised I haven't seen you around before.

g-2: ^Customer: "I heard you guys do more than boba. That right?"
g-3: ^Customer: "Like, you can tell me my future?"

c-5: ^ We just do bubble tea. Sorry. Can I get a name?
^"You know what I mean. Are we not allowed to talk about that, or something?"

c-0: ^. Can I get a name for the order?

c-6: ^. I have to make the drink first. Can I get a name?

g-4: ^Prinita: "Ah, it's just such a pain. Erik wants me to go back over to Brazil. He's found an artist over there, over in the favelas. He thinks he'll be big. He's doing a studio visit."

c-7: ^ You should give it a chance. It'll be a change of pace.
c-8: ^ Can't he hunt for artists over here instead?
c-9: ^ Maybe it's worth starting another life over there.
^Prinita: Uh, it really doesn't sound like my sort of thing.

g-8: ^Prinita: "He insists that we have to go with him. The artist has some big mural hanging up in his studio. Something about the neoliberal occupation of Brazilian consciousness. He's a big believer in art that can be political.
^Prinita: "And the artist is white, too. So it's...a fresh perspective. It's really cultural over there."

c-10: ^ Art has the power to change lives. Sell everything you own online and haul yourself over there.
c-12: ^ Tell him it's wrong! You can't get away with that kind of stuff anymore.

g-11: ^Prinita: "But he says we have to be lowkey about it. Don't tell our friends. He wants to bring a couple of the artists back and house them all in a studio here. Like a big sharehouse."

c-13: ^ Support local artists. I'm into it.
c-14: ^ You're really starting to make this sound like a bad idea.
c-15: ^ What is he going to do, make them paint for food?

read_fortune: ^Prinita: "Alright." She handed the drink back. "Tell me what they say."
^A little bit of milk slushed about at the bottom. The cup was wet with a few drops of condensation.
^I took the straw out. Carefully. I didn't want to disturb the pearls.

c-0: ^ What do you want to ask the pearls?

g-1: ^Prinita: "Whether I should leave my job and follow my partner to Brazil. Or leave them instead."

c-1: ^ You're sure you want the answer to that?
c-3: ^ Let's see what the pearls say.

g-2: ^I swirled it three times, tipped the leftovers onto a plate on the bench, counted to sixty and let it sit.

c-4: ^ I turned it three times, put the straw back in and tilted it so it pointed south.
c-5: ^It was exhausting, having to decide on the fate of everyone that came through here.
c-6: ^ I just had to get this one done, and then I could be alone again.

g-3: ^The pearls had melted but I could make out some shapes.

c-7: ^ Two starchy squiggles, stuck to the base of the cup.
^See the parallel lines? They symbolise travel, and also unity.
c-8: ^ Two starchy squiggles, stuck to the base of the cup.
^Those two lines, they mean you're going to travel somewhere, but it's going to be really rough. I would reconsider.
c-9: ^ You guys are going to be travelling in unison. Your paths will merge like rivers flowing in tandem.

g-4: ^The little arrow. Pointing north, but was that good? Or was it supposed to point south?

c-10: ^ You're going in the right direction.
^Prinita: "I'm not too confident about that, to be totally honest with you."
c-11: ^ You're going in the wrong direction, unfortunately.
^Prinita: "Ah, I think I understand what you mean..."
c-12: ^ The arrow is unclear. It could be pointing anywhere.
^That's a sign that what you're about to try, you're not really thinking it through.
^Prinita: "You're right. I'm just acting on an impulse. I should think about what this means for me."

g-5: ^And the smear of taro mixed with milk in the shape of an 'x'.

c-14: ^ Don't do it! The 'x' means that the decision is just plain wrong.
c-15: ^ And the 'x' means you're going in the wrong direction.
^Prinita: "I'm going to have to think a bit harder about this, is that what you're telling me?"

b: ^I think the pearls are pretty clear. Don't follow your husband to Brazil. Let him do his little art hunt by himself.

^You should be okay. Heed the warning. Think twice about whether you want to follow him over there.

^I was too tired to pay much attention. It took a lot out of me when I read the pearls.

^Prinita: "Okay. Thanks. They're just stupid pearls anyway. It's pretty stupid, staring at bubble tea and some stale milk."

^There's probably something drawing you there that you can't escape.

^You're going to end up following him there, but it's going to be rough.

^Prinita: "I know. I prepared myself for as much. Thanks anyway."

^I guess you have no choice but to follow him to Brazil.

^Prinita: "God damn it. I shouldn't have looked. It was going to screw up either way."

^Prinita looked at the cup one last time, as if looking would change things, and left.

customer_two: ^Customer: "Can I get a 'Blowing Every Last Dollar On My Disassociative Cam Girlfriend' Caramel Oolong Tea, please. No ice, heaps of sugar. Cold and large."

g-0: ^Nam: "You know, because you're listening, not going to lie but I'm pretty stressed right now."
g-1: ^Nam: "To be honest, I just don't think I'm going to make target this week."
^Nam: "You see, I work as an investment evangelist. For a fortune empowerment company. But don't call it a startup. We're not just that."
^Nam: "My job is to convince young people, in primary schools mostly, to get ahead on their investment portfolio while they're young."
^Nam: "The company has a deal with each school to send their evangelists in, so the kids can remember a friendly face whenever they see our logo."

c-3: ^ Getting them on the right track to success. It's what we all need in life.
^Nam: "That's right. Get them early and they'll get rich early too. I'm doing it for the kids, you see."
c-4: ^ So you pay schools out to force children to bank with you?
^Nam: "Not exactly like that, but yes, in a roundabout kinda way. God, it does seem kind of bad when you think about it."
c-5: ^ You...what? Get children to start investing their money when they're still in school?

g-5: ^Nam: "Anyway, it's going to be hard signing enough young people for this cycle."
^Nam: "My KPI is fifty kids. How do I do it?"

c-6: ^ Look, Nam. Can I be honest? These kids don't need financial advice. They don't need a credit card.
^Let them live, wild and free, like kids are meant to.
^Nam: "You're probably right. Money truly is evil..."
^Nam: "I'm going to burn all my money and move to Nepal!!"

c-0: ^ Mindfulness is immaterial. You won't need it. Spark the flame.
c-1: ^ ...maybe just keep a savings account, for backup, just in case?

c-7: ^ You're doing important work. These kids need to know how to manage their wealth, before it gets out of hand.
^Every child needs financial independence. The market defines our future.
^Nam: "Thank you. I needed to hear that. I know what I'm doing is critical. Wealth is everything!"

c-0: ^ The market is our god. Let it guide you like a flame in the night.
c-1: ^ Wait, maybe I got this wrong. This is not the path you want to take!!

c-8: ^Maybe think long and hard about the impact this might have. You're roping kids into something they barely understand. Maybe they should just wait until they're older?
^Nam: "...what am I doing with my life!!"

c-0: ^ Acknowledging what you've done wrong is the first step. I'll be here for you. We can work this out.
c-1: ^ It's no surprise that it'll be difficult. But at least you won't be ruining any young lives this way.

read_fortune: ^Nam: "Well, so, what happens now? Do I give you my cup? There are a few pearls left."
^He hands the finished drink over, with a few pearls squished together and left over.

c-0: ^ The pearls respond to a single question. Try to be specific.

g-1: ^Nam: "Should I quit and go to Nepal to become a yoga teacher?"
g-4: ^Three times, left to right. Turn the cup upside-down. I leant against the counter as we waited for a minute.
^Nam looked bothered by the whole process.

c-2: ^ Let's see what they have to say.

g-6: ^A wheel, each spoke clearly defined in strands of milk.

c-3: ^ Change is inevitable. Progress is coming, too.
c-4: ^ You have to keep pressing on. You're moving, you're rolling along in life.
^Now is not the time to leave that path.

g-7: ^The sign of an anchor made out in black splodges.

c-5: ^ It's just the beginning. You'll be downwards dogging into a stable existence.
c-6: ^ Don't throw it all away. Stick with what you're good at—selling debt to children.

c-7: ^ I see a fire...not entirely sure it's going to end well.
c-8: ^ I see a mountain. Nepal it is!

b: ^Helllooooo, Nepal! The pearls are in your favour.
^Good for you. I guess if yoga's really your thing, then you can go and do it.
^Well, if it doesn't work out you can always go back to finance...
^Ah, well. We're not all cut out to do what we want.

customer_three: ^Customer: Yeah, hi. Do you do boba?
^Customer: What's the name of that drink there? 'I'm Putting Protest Rally Facebook Event Links In My Twitter Bio For Social Capital' Taro and Orange Tea.

small_talk: ^Valeria: "So how does this work. I tell you a bit about myself, then I ask a question, and you tell me what's gonna happen?"
^Valeria: "I'm an artist. Was an artist, now work as more of a consultant these days. Freelance. Rent's too much in Berlin now that all the investors have moved in."
^Valeria: "You heard of DistEnZ? They make sneakers from ethically-sourced vegan material."
^Valeria: "After you're done with them, you can burn them for biofuel. Put it in your car, or something."
^Valeria: "I bounce between Colombia and Shenzhen sourcing materials. Most of it comes from recycled bullet casings we find buried in farms across Mongolia."

c-0: ^ Our planet is burning. Save it. Do your bit, and all.
c-1: ^ I don't really understand how bullet casings can be considered vegan. In any way.
^Valeria: "I mean, there are no animals involved. Right?"

g-5: ^Valeria: "Anyway, I'm having trouble. I thought the pearls might be able to guide my way."
^Valeria: "When I was an artist, I worked really hard to build up my name as a sustainable artist. I didn't create waste. I always reused things."
^Valeria: "The company want me to commission a huge sculpture of one of their signature shoes outside the factory in Shenzhen. Made of the bullet casings."

c-3: ^ It's probably a good use of resources.
c-4: ^ Do you want to be remembered by that? A big sneaker made from blood-stained bits of metal?
^Valeria: "No! I mean...no, it would ruin my reputation."
c-5: ^ A big sculpture? What's the point of that? Convince them to do something more useful than building a big monument to themselves.
^Valeria: "You're totally right. How arrogant. A big shoe, dedicated to themselves...what was I thinking??"

g-8: ^Valeria: "I want to take my art to another level. Not just making these big objects, you know what I mean?"
^Valeria: "I want to create moments that people remember. Strike the fear of God in their hearts with something impactful."
^Valeria: "You know, I've always had this idea to get a big pile of the shoes, like thousands, load them onto a raft, set it on fire and push it out to sea."

c-6: ^ It might be worth trying. I can see potential in it. As long as the message is there.
c-7: ^ But what about all the poisonous gas it's going to throw up into the air? And the shoes that are going to end up at the bottom of the ocean?
^Valerie: "Oh...I guess that was the last thing on my mind."
c-8: ^ Pure artistry in practice. They'll be having a retrospective on you next year. At MoMA.

g-11: ^Valeria: "I'm going to do this project. Now, how should I fund it?"

c-9: ^ Realistically, you can only make good art when you have rich friends willing to loan you a bit. Ask around. Do some DMs.
c-10: ^ You need a rich philanthropist behind you. Let them take you out to dinner, pamper you like a precious foreign dog.
c-11: ^ All good work takes time and hardship. Set up a fund online and ask people to donate. They'll appreciate the effort you're taking to be independent.

g-12: ^Valeria: "Thanks for listening. Now, should we see what the pearls say?"

read_fortune: ^Valeria: "Alright. Seems stupid to ask this to a cup, but..."
^Valeria: "Will I ever find someone I can call a partner?"

g-2: ^I could see through the cup that the pearls had melted into a series of indistinguishable shapes.
g-4: ^A squiggle, looking like a bunch of knots all tied up.

c-2: ^ It means anxiety. Thinking that you need to find a partner is causing you a lot of anxiety. You should avoid it.
c-3: ^ It symbolises meeting new people, getting tied up. It's a good thing - you're going to meet a lot of people and have the chance to try things out.
c-4: ^ No way. It's going to be a nightmare, whoever you get involved with.

g-5: ^A cup, or a glass of wine, or a goblet?

c-5: ^ It's going to turn out good. You guys are going to cruise through life and love every minute.
c-6: ^ You're going to find someone, but you'll lose a bit of yourself. There will be a hole, and you'll stare into it for as long as you're with them.
c-7: ^ You're going to love or hate this, but...I think you'll be hitting the bottle a bit more after finding a partner.

g-6: ^A circle with a dot in the centre—a sun.

c-9: ^ You're destined to be a power couple.
c-10: ^ It'll work out for you. Success is in your future.

b: ^You're going to be the perfect power couple. Gallery openings will fear you.
^People are going to love tagging you in their photos. You'll find someone, for sure.
^It's not that bad being alone. You'll have space to, you know, build more shoe sculptures.

^Sorry, it just looks like it won't work out for you. Maybe it's worth considering another profession.

^Yoga, even?
